prompt:
I have the following count table for an RNA-seq experiment, rows are genes and columns are samples, "Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx". The first column of the file is my gene names and the rest of the columns are samples. My annotation data is here  "SRP021193.colData.tsv", it contains sample annotations and rows of this matches the columns of count table, first column is the sample ids. Find genes specific for each "group" in my annotation data  using statistical tests. Plot PCA only using "group" specific genes and color code PCA by "group" variable in my annotation data.

here are first few lines of the file(s).

Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx:
Genes	CASE_1	CASE_2	CASE_3	CASE_4	CASE_5	CASE_6	CTRL_1	CTRL_2	CTRL_3	CTRL_4	CTRL_5	CTRL_6
TSPAN6	9832	25521	23529	0	32	0	10558	20573	6507	0	0	 0
TNMD	3281	 7167	 3435	0	 0	0	  202	  403	 203	0	0	21


SRP021193.colData.tsv:
	diagnosis	group	LibrarySelection
CASE_1	non-ischemic cardiomyopathy	CASE	cDNA


response:
```
# Load necessary libraries
library(openxlsx)
library(dplyr)
library(stats)
library(ggplot2)

# Read count data
count_data <- read.xlsx("Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx", sheet = 1, startRow = 2, colNames = TRUE)

# Read annotation data
annotation_data <- read.delim("SRP021193.colData.tsv", header = TRUE, sep = "\t")

# Remove empty columns from count data
count_data <- count_data[, colSums(count_data[-1]) > 0]

# Get group-specific genes using statistical tests
group_specific_genes <- list()

groups <- unique(annotation_data$group)
for (group in groups) {
  group_samples <- annotation_data$group == group
  group_counts <- count_data[, group_samples]

  # Check if there are enough observations for statistical tests
  if (sum(group_samples) > 0 && sum(!group_samples) > 0) {

    # Perform statistical tests (e.g., t-test, ANOVA) to identify group-specific genes
    group_specific_genes[[group]] <- apply(group_counts, 1, function(x) {
      if (length(unique(x)) > 1) {
        p_value <- try(t.test(x[group_samples], x[!group_samples])$p.value, silent = TRUE)
        if (!is.na(p_value) && p_value < 0.05) {
          return(names(x))
        }
      }
    })

  }
}

# Combine group-specific genes into a single vector
group_specific_genes <- unlist(group_specific_genes, use.names = FALSE)

# Filter count data using group-specific genes
filtered_count_data <- count_data[group_specific_genes, ]

# Perform PCA using filtered count data
if (ncol(filtered_count_data) > 1) {
  pca_data <- prcomp(t(filtered_count_data[, -1]))

  # Create PCA plot
  pca_plot <- ggplot(data = as.data.frame(pca_data$x), aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = annotation_data$group)) +
    geom_point() +
    labs(x = "PC1", y = "PC2", color = "Group") +
    theme_minimal()

  # Print PCA plot
  print(pca_plot)
} else {
  print("Not enough samples for PCA analysis")
}
```

Note: I have added an additional check to ensure that there are enough samples for performing PCA analysis. If there are not enough samples, the code will display a message instead of raising an error.
